awd_abstract_narration:
Oceans and other water bodies cover over 70% of Earth's surface, shrouding critical geologic regimes, natural resource deposits, and ecosystems. Obtaining a deeper understanding of the processes occurring on Earth requires unique strategies and innovative technologies, as well as strong collaborations across the shoreline, between scientific disciplines, and through international and industry partnerships. To address this priority, a two-day, science-focused symposium will be convened uniting the seismological and marine geoscience community. The symposium will enable scientists and program managers to share exciting new science results, discuss future directions and key scientific questions, promote and empower early career scientists by showcasing their work and providing networking opportunities, and communicate changes to critical marine seismic infrastructure so that research can be successfully planned, funded, and conducted using existing and evolving tools. This symposium is critical for maintaining the health of the marine seismic research community and will facilitate progress toward better understanding of frontier science topics such as the processes related to geohazards like megathrust earthquakes, tsunamis, undersea landslides, and volcanic eruptions as well as the processes that control the formation and evolution of ocean basins. 


The University National Oceanographic Laboratory System-Marine Seismic Research Oversight Committee (UNOLS-MSROC) and the Ocean Bottom Seismograph Instrument Pool Oversight Committee identified a priority to organize a symposium for the seismological and marine geoscience community. This symposium will accomplish the following goals: 1) Showcase research in marine seismology using new technology to achieve innovative observational datasets with an emphasis on open-access and interdisciplinary or international projects. 2) Reach out to seismology subject-matter experts in international, industry, terrestrial, defense, and extra-terrestrial environments to enhance cross-community interactions, leveraging of resources, and collaborations. 3) Facilitate networking and promote brainstorming of new ideas between seismologists at all stages in their careers. 4) Lower barriers to access marine seismology facilities in the non-seismology marine science and onshore seismological communities by providing information on marine seismic facilities and promoting collaborations with marine seismologists. 5) Expand community knowledge of seismic data management and sharable resources. 6) Allow for a broader seismology community, including new scientists, industry, and international participants, and incorporate discussions of topics of common interest.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
1.   Introduction

This proposal was originally funded to plan, organize, and hold a two-day, science-focused Marine Seismology Symposium to convene the seismological and marine geoscience community and facilitate its growth in advancing science discoveries. The in-person conference was originally scheduled and booked for September 2020, then moved back to March 2021 at the same venue due to pandemic related travel restrictions. As these travel restrictions continued, it was clear an in-person event would not be able to be held in March 2021 and the organizing committee decided to pivot to a virtual symposium.

 

The Marine Seismology Symposium was held over two weeks, March 8-19th 2021. The symposium included 40 hours of live events held over two weeks and additional asynchronous interactions supported by a user-friendly online platform. Overall, a combination of excellent contributed presentations and careful logistical planning produced a successful Marine Seismology Symposium that fulfilled all six of the goals set in the proposal and outlined below:

  1. Showcase research in marine seismology using new technology to achieve innovative observational datasets.
  2. Reach out to seismology subject-matter experts in international, industry, terrestrial, defense, and extra-terrestrial environments to enhance cross-community interactions, leveraging of resources, and collaborations.
  3. Facilitate networking and promote brainstorming of new ideas among seismologists at all stages in their careers.
  4. Lower barriers to access marine seismology facilities in the non-seismology marine science and onshore seismological communities by providing information on marine seismic facilities and promoting collaborations with marine seismologists.
  5. Expand community knowledge of seismic data management and sharable resources.
  6. Allow for a broader seismology community, including new scientists, industry, and international participants, and incorporate discussions of topics of common interest.

 

The Marine Seismology Symposium Organizing Committee and Team consisted of Kasey Aderhold (IRIS), Emily Roland (WWU), Masako Tominaga (WHOI), Anne Tre'hu (OSU), Bob Woodward (IRIS), Patrick Hart (USGS), Donna Shillington (NAU), Sean Higgins (LDEO), Sean Gulick (UTIG), Monica Kohler (Caltech), Helen Janiszewski (U of Hawaii, Manoa), Lindsay Worthington (UNM), Anne Be'cel (LDEO), John Orcutt (SIO), Guilherme de Melo (UFRN), Jianhua Gong (SIO), Liam Moser (WHOI), Krystin Poitra (IRIS), and Molly Staats (IRIS).

 

We used the remaining funding to support the only objective of this award that the virtual symposium could not fulfill: bringing marine seismology community members physically together to present, discuss, and network at a scientific meeting. These meetings included the 2022 SSA Annual Meeting, the 2022 SAGE/GAGE Workshop, the 2022 SEG-AGU Geophysics of Convergent Margins conference, and the 2022 SZ4D Community Workshop.

2.   Intellectual Merit

Marine seismology is a field that has applications and contributors across a wide range of disciplines including engineering, computational sciences, and more. Support for presenters and attendees coming from these other fields was achieved by not requiring a fee to attend and holding this event virtually, effectively lowering barriers to participation. Sessions like Harnessing Frontier Technologies and Frontiers in Marine Electromagnetics continued building relationships across fields and applications. Community infrastructure resources like the Ocean Bottom Seismographic Instrument Center benefitted from the community gathering to feature the science they enable and for community members to discuss future directions and needs.

 

Recordings from the virtual symposium are available on the IRIS Earthquake Science Presentations YouTube playlist at: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLvd8fqCFf8CXWMRdwsRk3Ixi2xOEb0I_6.

 

At the 2022 SSA Annual Meeting, a "Frontiers in Marine Seismology" session was proposed and organized by 7 co-conveners, predominantly students and early career researchers. Submitted abstracts were organized into a poster session and oral session.

3.   Broader Impacts

There were 463 people registered to attend the virtual symposium, with less than a third indicating that they had decided to attend the postponed in-person 2020 Marine Seismology Symposium. At least 150 additional attendees were brought in due to the pivot to a virtual symposium, likely with a significant international representation. Registered attendees represented an even distribution of both experience with marine seismology as well as career stages.

 

We included early career and student representatives on the virtual symposium organizing committee. The first day of the virtual symposium included a session specifically aimed at students and early career researchers to help navigate the planning and execution of a marine seismology experiment. All session conveners were given guidance for including early career researchers as invited presenters in their sessions, and the speaker make-up of the overall program was monitored by the organizing committee.

 

The travel support enabled  students and early career researchers to attend and present at a scientific meeting,  many their first ever due to pandemic-related travel restrictions. In addition to the formal program components at SSA, informal meet-ups were organized for marine seismology community members during the lunch break each day. This encouraged greater interaction and networking among session co-conveners and meeting attendees.
